awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase II: Collaborative Research:  I/UCRC Center for Surveillance Research, Phase II
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Surveillance Research (CSR) was founded in 2010 as a Phase I NSF I/UCRC. This award enables the Center to become a  Phase 2 I/UCRC. Both founding sites of the Center, at Wright State University and at Ohio State University, will move to Phase 2. The main objective of CSR is to develop the theory and practice for modern surveillance. It has a healthy membership profile that has a mix of federal and industry members.  In Phase 2, Wright State University seeks to become the Lead Site of the Center, as opposed to Phase 1 lead site of Ohio State. The fundamental intellectual issues addressed by the Center's continuing research portfolio have immediate application in application domains including medical imaging, transportation, and law enforcement.  Further, the center will continue to host summer internship programs, in collaboration with the Air Force Minority Leaders Program and others, to attract participation by a diverse population of students.

While use of sensor technology is pervasive in modern society, fundamental questions about the performance of sensor systems remain unaddressed. The inability to answer these questions, or even properly phrase the questions, impacts not only the development of sensors themselves, but also the development of data exploitation algorithms. Further, these unanswered questions are critical for eventually providing human users the ability to understanding the reliability of sensor performance under new and changing operating conditions. Specifically, sensors are developed under an assumed mode of use, and the exploitation algorithms are then left to extract whatever information the resultant sensor may afford, without that prior development having been properly informed by a realistic performance model. Moreover, the exploitation algorithms themselves are developed under presumed statistical models that may have varying degrees of agreement with actual sensor phenomenology, and these algorithms are then trained (e.g., to set operating parameters) based on a representative set of training measurements. However, the sensor community lacks any means to propagate mismatch between statistical assumptions and sensor phenomenology, or mismatch between training data and operational data, into the sensor algorithm or to even reliably predict a sensor's ultimate performance. Under Phase II, the Center for Surveillance Research will continue to address these shortcomings in existing sensor technology.

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Surveillance Research (CSR) is a National Science Foundation Industry / University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) whose mission is to develop a principled theory and advanced practice for modern sensing systems. CSR is a collaborative effort by academia, government, and industry to conduct pre competitive research and student training for the next generation of technology leaders.  NSF investment in science and education is leveraged over six to one by the financial support of the Centers participating members. Annually, the Centers Ohio State University site has supported six to ten students on projects collaboratively formulated and selected with the Centers Industry Advisory Board. Project review, critique, and selection were performed at the semi annual IAB meetings;

Center objectives include student training, research, development, discovery, and documentation in the theory and practice of remote sensing. Emphasis is on National defense and security applications. During the Phase 2 effort, nine Center members and two university sites participated in the Center.  At the Ohio State University site, 35 US citizen students were mentored through Center activities, including 19 graduate students.

Towards the goal of student training, the center has graduated over three dozen US citizen students. On average, four graduates each year have taken employment in government research and development, supporting the defense and security of the US.

Significant theoretical results have been obtained in high-dimensional inference, with theoretical results reported in peer reviewed journal articles and techniques applied to multiple remote sensing applications, including: hyperspectral imaging, laser vibrometry, polarimetric imaging, radar change detection, object tracking, waveform detection, and GPS denied navigation. The Centers researchers have led the field of compressive radar, including participation in NATO technology panels. Basic science and machine learning results have been disseminated through peer-reviewed publication; and, tools and techniques have been applied to controlled and classified data sets during student internships with participating government laboratories.

Center technology has additionally impacted cardiac magnetic resonance image through devlopment of Bayesian modeling, message passing computation, and other machine learning techniques.  These technologies enable, for example, five-minute scans providing full 3D heart coverage with assessment of both the heart muscle and hemodynamics. Cardiac disease is a leading cause of death in the US. CMR provides potential for comprehensive assessment, providing early detection and detailed guidance of proper intervention.
